title.rendered: Nick Kyrgios Withdraws From Wimbledon With Wrist Injury

content.rendered:
Nick Kyrgios withdrew from Wimbledon on Sunday with a wrist injury, stripping the tournament of one of its headline acts. This is 12 months after the firebrand Australian finished runner-up to Novak Djokovic.

(Read Also : BCCI announces India women’s squad, schedule for Bangladesh T20Is and ODIs)

Nick Kyrgios withdrew from Wimbledon on Sunday with a wrist injury. This stripped the tournament of one of its headline acts 12 months after the firebrand Australian finished runner-up to Novak Djokovic. “I’m really sad to say that I have to withdraw from Wimbledon this year,” the 28-year-old wrote on Instagram, explaining that he had hurt his wrist as he prepared to play in Mallorca last week. Kyrgios had been an injury doubt in the Wimbledon build-up. However, that was because he was struggling to recover from knee surgery which restricted him to just one match in 2023.

“I tried my hardest to be ready after my surgery and step on the Wimbledon courts again. During my comeback, I experienced some wrist pain during Mallorca,” he added.

“As a precaution, I had it scanned and it showed a torn ligament in my wrist.

“I tried everything to be able to play and I am disappointed to say that I just didn’t have enough time to manage it before Wimbledon.

“I’ll be back, and I appreciate your support.”

Kyrgios faced wild card David Goffin in the first round at the All England Club on Monday.

His place in the draw will be taken by a lucky loser from qualifying.

Earlier Sunday, Kyrgios, whose lone match in 2023 came in Stuttgart last month, said his battle to regain full fitness had been “brutal”.

‘Dreading coming back’

However, he added: “I didn’t miss the sport. I was almost dreading coming back a little bit, but it’s my job.”

He also admitted there remained “question marks” about his ability to play best-of-five sets after such a lengthy absence.

“I feel like to the outside world, people don’t understand. Just because it’s not contact, it’s not that physical.

“I dare someone to step out there and play for four hours with Novak and see how you feel afterwards.”

At Wimbledon in 2022, the Australian dominated most headlines.

His high-octane, flamboyant shot-making was accompanied by signature clashes with rivals and officialdom.

He was fined $10,000 for spitting and $4,000 for shouting obscenities — one of which sent British tabloids into meltdown as it was within earshot of eight-year-old Prince George.

Kyrgios also fought out an explosive third round clash with Stefanos Tsitsipas with the Greek even describing him as “evil” and a “bully”.

In the final against Djokovic, he demanded a woman be ejected from the crowd for consuming “700 drinks, bro”.

“In a way it was comforting to be home. Obviously heartbreaking as well,” said Kyrgios as he reflected on his time out of the sport.

“Last year I felt like everything kind of came together for me. Finals of Wimbledon. Barely lost a match. Had the third best season on tour.

“Obviously my body was just crying out for some sort of rest.”

For Kyrgios, being away from the tennis courts didn’t mean an absence from the public view.

In May, his car was stolen from his mother at gunpoint outside the family home in Canberra.

Before that incident, Kyrgios pleaded guilty in February to assaulting a former girlfriend.

He avoided a conviction for what the magistrate called a “single act of stupidity”.

Kyrgios has also been the headliner in the Netflix series “Break Point” where he spoke candidly about his mental health.

He admitted he considered suicide and ended up in a psychiatric ward in 2019.

“It took me seven, eight years to be able to just open up about that,” he explained on Sunday.
